prompt.p: A 19-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus is seen in the outpatients’ clinic. She has been on subcutaneous insulin for 4 years. Her diary of home fingerstick glucose levels is very variable. A glycosylated haemoglobin is 11.2%.
To prevent long-term vascular complications what should her glycosylated haemoglobin be?

choiceInteraction.simpleChoice: Aim for a glycosylated haemoglobin of less than 4.0%
Aim for a glycosylated haemoglobin of 4.0–6.9%
Aim for a glycosylated haemoglobin of 7–7.5%
Aim for a glycosylated haemoglobin of 7.6–11.0%
Aim for a glycosylated haemoglobin of greater than 11.0%

modalFeedback.p: Option C is Correct. The National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) recommends a target level of glycosylated haemoglobin of less than 7.5% in patients with type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Option A is Incorrect. This target glycosylated haemoglobin is too low and would be associated with a significant risk of episodes of hypoglycaemia.

Option B is Incorrect. Whilst the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) recommends a target glycosylated haemoglobin level of less than 6.5% in those at increased arterial risk (e.g. previous stroke or myocardial infarction), this patient does not fit this criterion.
Option D is Incorrect. This target glycosylated haemoglobin is too high and would be associated with an increased long-term risk of vascular complications.
Option E is Incorrect. This target glycosylated haemoglobin is too high and would be associated with an increased long-term risk of vascular complications.
